text.p: These are the main stories in Latvian newspapers on Tuesday. Prepared for Reuters by the Co-operation Fund. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy:
- In a TV address President Ulmanis warned voters against trusting the populism of political parties. He also spoke about the need to observe moral principles in politics.
- Polish authorities have not yet succeeded in catching the criminals who attacked a Latvian tourist coach killing one passenger and taking away 38,000 marks and $250.
- Three independent deputies, Leopolds Ozolins, Gundars Valdmanis and Andris Rubins have created a parliamentary group, Tikai Tevzemei (Only for Fatherland).

- The speaker of the Lithuanian parliament, Vytautas Landsbergis, said there is no border dispute between Latvia and Lithuania but that the problem was the delimitation of economic areas. He dismissed remarks by Latvian PM Andris Shkele that Lithuania was acting deliberately to delay talks with Latvia.

- Parliament's judicial committee, which is in the process of revising the law on compulsory motor insurance, has approved new insurance tariffs which are about 50 percent higher than the previous ones. On March 10, the draft is likely to be put to the vote in parliament.

- The consideration of the case of Alexei Vidavski, the mayor of eastern town Daugavpils who is likely to be banned from the local elections for having been an active member of the Communist Party after January 13, 1991, was postponed due to the illness of the judge. As a result, Vidavski will run in the election.
